event: Reggie Miller scores 8 points in 9 seconds to stun the Knicks in 1995.
Michael Jordan scored 226 points in the Bulls’ five-game Eastern Conference first round series against Cleveland, breaking Bernard King’s record of 213 set in 1984.
Led by Andre Iguodala’s 20 points, the 8-seed 76ers upset the 1-seed Bulls in Game 6 to win their first-round series. It marked the second straight year a No. 8 beat a No. 1 in Round 1.

The Portland Trail Blazers defeated the host Phoenix Suns 153-151 in double-overtime in Game 4 of their Western Conference Semifinal Round series, the highest-scoring NBA Playoff game ever. The Blazers went on to win the series in five games.

Kawhi Leonard hit a shot from the corner over Joel Embiid at the buzzer that bounced off the rim four times before falling to give the Toronto Raptors a 92-90 victory over the 76ers on Sunday night in Game 7 of the Eastern Conference semifinal series.
Philadelphia’s Allen Iverson recorded an NBA playoff-record 10 steals in a 97-85 win over the Orlando Magic.
Larry Bird scored 27 points and Cedric Maxwell added 19 to lead Boston to a 102-91 victory over Houston in Game 6 of the Finals, giving the Celtics their 14th NBA Championship.
Magic Johnson notched a playoff record 24 assists as the Lakers beat Phoenix 118-102 in Game 2 of the West Finals.

Rookie guard Magic Johnson filled in at center for the injured Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and came up with 42 points, 15 rebounds and seven assists as the Los Angeles Lakers won the NBA title by beating Philadelphia 123-107 in Game 6 of the Finals.

Michael Jordan knocks down a contested fadeaway at the buzzer in Game 4 over Gerald Wilkins to defeat the Cavs 103-101 in the Eastern Conference finals. With the win, the Bulls clinch their third straight NBA Finals berth.
Rick Barry hit a jumper with 38 seconds remaining to put Game 1 of the NBA Finals out of reach as Golden State defeated Washington 101-95.

A Game 4 win against the Portland Trail Blazers in the Western Conference finals sends the Golden State Warriors to The Finals for a fifth straight postseason. They join the 1960s Boston Celtics (10 total) as the only teams in NBA history to make The Finals in five consecutive seasons or more.
With a 105-97 win over the Detroit Pistons at Chicago Stadium in Game 2 of their Eastern Conference Final series, the Chicago Bulls set an NBA playoff record for consecutive wins at home with 15.

Dominique Wilkins and Larry Bird traded bucket for bucket in the fourth quarter of Game 7 of the 1988 Eastern Conference Semifinals until Boston escaped with a 118-116 victory. Wilkins finished with 47 points and Bird had 34 — with 20 of his points tallied in the fourth quarter.

Paul Pierce outscores the New Jersey Nets 19-16 in the fourth quarter to help the Boston Celtics erase a 21-point deficit in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference Finals. The 94-90 victory remains the biggest comeback in NBA Playoff history.
The Chicago Bulls defeat the Detroit Pistons in Game 4 to clinch the franchise’s first trip to The Finals.
Golden State’s Klay Thompson sinks an NBA playoff-record 11 3-pointers to power the Warriors’ 108-101 comeback win against the Oklahoma City Thunder in Game 6 of the Western Conference finals.
Cleveland Cavaliers forward LeBron James scored the team’s final 25 points in a double-overtime win against the Detroit Pistons in Game 5 of the Eastern Conference finals.
Indiana’s Reggie Miller drilled an NBA playoffs record five 3-pointers in the fourth quarter of the Pacers’ 93-86 win over host New York in Game 5 of the Eastern Conference finals.
Golden State’s Stephen Curry nails nine 3-pointers in a 122-103 win in Game 2 vs. the Cleveland Cavaliers, breaking Ray Allen’s record for the most 3-pointers in an NBA Finals game.

Down 15 points with 10:28 to go in Game 7 of the Western Conference finals, the Los Angeles Lakers stage an epic comeback against the Portland Trail Blazers. The Lakers outscore the Blazers 29-11 down the stretch, clinching the victory off a Kobe Bryant-to-Shaquille O’Neal alley-oop with 40 seconds left.

New York, led by Patrick Ewing’s 24 points and 22 rebounds, defeated Indiana 94-90 at Madison Square Garden in Game 7 of the Eastern Conference Finals, sending the Knicks to the NBA Finals for the first time since 1973.
Philadelphia held Los Angeles center Kareem Abdul-Jabbar to his all-time playoff low of six points and trounced the Lakers 135-102 in Game 5 of the NBA Finals.

The Chicago Bulls defeat the Utah Jazz 96-54 in the most lopsided game in the history of the NBA Finals. The 54 points by the Jazz is also an NBA record for fewest points in a game since the inception of the 24-second shot clock.
Jerry West hits a 60-foot shot to force overtime in 1970 NBA Finals Game 3.
Michael Jordan's 'Flu Game' leads Bulls to victory in 1997 NBA Finals Game 5.
Cedric Maxwell scored 24 points and Boston outrebounded Los Angeles 52-33 to beat the Lakers 111-102 in a Game 7 Finals showdown at Boston Garden, giving the Celtics their 15th NBA championship.
The Detroit Pistons completed a Finals sweep of the Los Angeles Lakers with a 105-97 Game 4 victory, winning the first NBA title in franchise history.
Michael Jordan clinches his sixth championship with Bulls in 1998 NBA Finals Game 6.
Tim Duncan and the San Antonio Spurs win their fifth NBA title, defeating the Miami Heat 104-87 in Game 5 and taking The NBA Finals 4-1. Rising star Kawhi Leonard is the Finals MVP.
The Golden State Warriors close out the Cleveland Cavaliers in Game 6 of the 2015 Finals, 105-97, for the first championship for the Bay Area team since 1975. Andre Iguodala is the Finals MVP.

The Boston Celtics win their 17th NBA Championship, defeating the Lakers 4 games to 2. Boston’s 131-92 win in Game 6 is the most lopsided closeout win in NBA Finals history. Paul Pierce is named Finals MVP.
Ray Allen's clutch three-pointer forces overtime in 2013 NBA Finals Game 6.

Shaquille O’Neal is named unanimous Most Valuable Player of NBA Finals 2000 following the Lakers’ 116-111 Game 6 victory, receiving all seven votes from a national media panel. O’Neal averaged 38 points, 16.7 rebounds and 2.67 blocks in the six-game Finals series.

LeBron James and the Miami Heat won their second straight NBA championship, taking an epic series 4-3 with a Game 7 win over the San Antonio Spurs, 95-88. LeBron was named Finals MVP for the second straight year.
